metadata.title_en: Title and Extent
metadata.text_en: This Act shall be called the Myanmar Penal Code, and shall extend to the whole of Myanmar.

metadata.title_en: Punishment of Offences Within Myanmar
metadata.text_en: Every person shall be liable to punishment under this Code for any act or omission contrary to its provisions committed within Myanmar.

metadata.title_en: Extra-Territorial Jurisdiction
metadata.text_en: Any person liable under Myanmar law to be tried for an offence committed beyond Myanmar shall be dealt with under this Code.

metadata.title_en: Punishment of Offences Committed Beyond, But Punishable Within, Myanmar
metadata.text_en: The provisions of this Code apply also to any offence committed by— (1) any citizen of Myanmar in any place without and beyond Myanmar; (2) any person on any ship or aircraft registered in the Union of Myanmar wherever it may be.

metadata.title_en: Certain Laws Not to be Affected by This Act
metadata.text_en: Nothing in this Code is intended to repeal, vary, suspend or affect any of the provisions of any Act for punishing mutiny and desertion of officers, soldiers, sailors or airmen in the service of the Government of the Union of Myanmar, or the provisions of any special or local law.

metadata.title_en: Definitions in the Code to be Understood Subject to Exceptions
metadata.text_en: Throughout this Code every definition of an offence, every penal provision and every illustration of every such definition or penal provision, shall be understood subject to the exceptions contained in the Chapter entitled "General Exceptions", though those exceptions are not repeated in such definition, penal provision or illustration.

metadata.title_en: Sense of Expression Once Explained
metadata.text_en: Every expression which is explained in any part of this Code is used in every part of this Code in conformity with the explanation.

metadata.title_en: Gender Pronoun
metadata.text_en: The pronoun 'he' and its derivatives are used of any person, whether male or female.

metadata.title_en: Number
metadata.text_en: Unless the contrary appears from the context, words importing the singular number include the plural number, and words importing the plural number include the singular number.

metadata.title_en: Man, Woman
metadata.text_en: The word 'man' denotes a male human being of any age; the word 'woman' denotes a female human being of any age.

metadata.title_en: Person
metadata.text_en: The word 'person' includes any Company or Association, or body of persons, whether incorporated or not.

metadata.title_en: Public
metadata.text_en: The word 'public' includes any class of the public or any community.

metadata.title_en: Queen
metadata.text_en: The word 'Queen' is omitted.

metadata.title_en: Servant of Government
metadata.text_en: The words 'servant of Government' denote any officer or servant continued, appointed or employed in Myanmar by or under the authority of the Union Government or any Regional Government or State Government or by a local authority.

metadata.title_en: British India
metadata.text_en: The words 'British India' are omitted.

metadata.title_en: Government of India
metadata.text_en: The words 'Government of India' are omitted.

metadata.title_en: Government
metadata.text_en: The word 'Government' denotes the Union Government or any Regional Government or State Government.

metadata.title_en: Myanmar
metadata.text_en: The word 'Myanmar' denotes the territories which for the time being are comprised within the Union of Myanmar.

metadata.title_en: Judge
metadata.text_en: The word 'Judge' denotes not only every person who is officially designated as a Judge, but also every person who is empowered by law to give in any legal proceeding, civil or criminal, a definitive judgment, or a judgment which, if not appealed against, would be definitive, or a judgment which is definitive only if confirmed by some other authority, or by whom a body of persons is empowered by law to give a definitive judgment or a judgment which, if not appealed against, would be definitive, or a judgment which is definitive only if confirmed by some other authority.

metadata.title_en: Court of Justice
metadata.text_en: The words 'Court of Justice' denote a Judge who is empowered by law to act judicially alone, or a body of Judges which is empowered by law to act judicially as a body, when such Judge or body of Judges is acting judicially.

metadata.title_en: Public Servant
Movable Property
metadata.text_en: The words 'movable property' are intended to include corporeal property of every description, except land and things attached to the earth, or permanently fastened to anything which is attached to the earth.

metadata.title_en: Wrongful gain
metadata.text_en: 'Wrongful gain' is gain by unlawful means of property to which the person gaining is not legally entitled. 'Wrongful loss' is the loss by unlawful means of property to which the person losing it is legally entitled. A person is said to gain wrongfully when such person retains wrongfully, as well as when such person acquires wrongfully. A person is said to lose wrongfully when such person is wrongfully kept out of any property, as well as when such person is wrongfully deprived of property.

metadata.title_en: Dishonestly
metadata.text_en: Whoever does anything with the intention of causing wrongful gain to one person or wrongful loss to another person, is said to do that thing "dishonestly".

metadata.title_en: Fraudulently
metadata.text_en: A person is said to do a thing "fraudulently" if he does that thing with intent to defraud but not otherwise.

metadata.title_en: Reason to believe
metadata.text_en: A person is said to have "reason to believe" a thing, if he has sufficient cause to believe that thing, but not otherwise.

metadata.title_en: Property in possession of wife, clerk or servant
metadata.text_en: When property is in the possession of a person's wife, clerk or servant, on account of that person, it is in that person's possession within the meaning of this Code.

metadata.title_en: Counterfeit
metadata.text_en: A person is said to 'counterfeit' who causes one thing to resemble another thing, intending by means of such resemblance to practise deception, or knowing it to be likely that deception will thereby be practised. (Exception—It is not essential to counterfeiting that the imitation should be exact. The imitation should be such that it might deceive an ordinary person.)

metadata.title_en: Document
metadata.text_en: The word 'document' denotes any matter expressed or described upon any substance by means of letters, figures or marks, or by more than one of those means, intended to be used, or which may be used, as evidence of that matter. (Illustrations—A writing expressing the terms of a contract, which may be used as evidence of the contract, is a document. A map or plan which may be used as evidence is a document. A writing containing directions or instructions is a document. The impression of a seal upon a writing is a document. Any words on a tablet, or an inscription on a metal plate or stone, is a document.)

metadata.title_en: Valuable Security
metadata.text_en: The words 'valuable security' denote a document which is, or purports to be, a document whereby any legal right is created, extended, transferred, restricted, extinguished or released, or whereby any person acknowledges that he lies under legal liability, or has not a certain legal right. (Illustrations—A writes his name on the back of a bill of exchange. This endorsement is a 'valuable security', as it transfers the right to the bill to any person who may become the lawful holder of it. A executes a promissory note whereby he acknowledges that he owes B a certain sum of money. This promissory note is a 'valuable security', as it is a document whereby A acknowledges that he is under legal liability to B. )

metadata.title_en: A Will
metadata.text_en: The words 'a will' denote any testamentary document.

metadata.title_en: Words Referring to Acts Include Illegal Omissions
metadata.text_en: In every part of this Code, except where a contrary intention appears from the context, words which refer to acts done extend also to illegal omissions.

metadata.title_en: "Act", "Omission"
metadata.text_en: The word 'act' denotes as well a series of acts as a single act; the word 'omission' denotes as well a series of omissions as a single omission.

metadata.title_en: Acts Done by Several Persons in Furtherance of Common Intention
metadata.text_en: When a criminal act is done by several persons in furtherance of the common intention of all, each of such persons is liable for that act in the same manner as if it were done by him alone.

metadata.title_en: When Such an Act is Criminal by Reason of its Being Done with a Criminal Knowledge or Intention
metadata.text_en: Whenever an act, which is criminal only by reason of its being done with a criminal knowledge or intention, is done by several persons, each of such persons who joins in the act with such knowledge or intention is liable for the act in the same manner as if the act were done by him alone with that knowledge or intention.

metadata.title_en: Effect Caused Partly by Act and Partly by Omission
metadata.text_en: Wherever the causing of a certain effect, or an attempt to cause that effect, by an act or by an omission, is an offence, it is to be understood that the causing of that effect partly by an act and partly by an omission is the same offence.

metadata.title_en: Co-operation by Doing One of Several Acts Constituting an Offence
metadata.text_en: When an offence is committed by means of several acts, whoever intentionally co-operates in the commission of that offence by doing any one of those acts, either singly or jointly with any other person, commits that offence.

metadata.title_en: Persons Concerned in Criminal Act May be Guilty of Different Offences
metadata.text_en: Where several persons are engaged or concerned in the commission of a criminal act, they may be guilty of different offences by means of that act.

metadata.title_en: Voluntarily
metadata.text_en: A person is said to cause an effect "voluntarily" when he causes it by means whereby he intended to cause it, or by means which, at the time of employing those means, he knew or had reason to believe to be likely to cause it. (Illustrations—A sets fire, by night, to an inhabited house in a large town, for the purpose of facilitating a robbery and thus causes the death of a person. Here, A may not have intended to cause death, and may even be sorry that death has been caused by his act. But since he knew that he was likely to cause death by setting fire to an inhabited house, he has caused death voluntarily. )

metadata.title_en: Offence
metadata.text_en: The word 'offence' denotes a thing punishable by this Code, or by any special or local law, as hereinafter defined.

metadata.title_en: Special Law
metadata.text_en: A 'special law' is a law applicable to a particular subject.

metadata.title_en: Local Law
metadata.text_en: A 'local law' is a law applicable only to a particular part of Myanmar.

metadata.title_en: Illegal
metadata.text_en: The word 'illegal' is applicable to everything which is an offence, or which is prohibited by law, or which furnishes ground for a civil action; and a person is said to be 'legally bound to do' whatever it is illegal in him to omit.

metadata.title_en: Injury
metadata.text_en: The word 'injury' denotes any harm whatever illegally caused to any person, in body, mind, reputation or property.

metadata.title_en: Life
metadata.text_en: The word 'life' denotes the life of a human being, unless the contrary appears from the context.

metadata.title_en: Death
metadata.text_en: The word 'death' denotes the death of a human being, unless the contrary appears from the context.

metadata.title_en: Animal
metadata.text_en: The word 'animal' denotes any living creature, other than a human being.

metadata.title_en: Vessel
metadata.text_en: The word 'vessel' denotes anything made for the conveyance by water of human beings or of property.

metadata.title_en: Year, Month
metadata.text_en: Wherever the word 'year' or the word 'month' is used, it is to be understood that the year or the month is to be reckoned according to the British calendar.

metadata.title_en: Section
metadata.text_en: The word 'section' denotes one of the portions of a Chapter of this Code which are distinguished by numerical figures.

metadata.title_en: Oath
metadata.text_en: The word 'oath' includes a solemn affirmation substituted by law for an oath, and any declaration required or authorized by law to be made before a public servant, or to be used for the purpose of proof, whether in a Court of Justice or not.

metadata.title_en: Good faith
metadata.text_en: Nothing is said to be done or believed in 'good faith' which is done or believed without due care and attention.

metadata.title_en: Harbour
metadata.text_en: Except in section 157 and in section 130 in the case in which the harbour is given by the wife or husband of the offender, the word 'harbour' in sections 212, 216 and 216A, and in the second paragraph of section 216B, is explained as follows: When any person harbours another person, knowing or having reason to believe that such other person is a person whom he is legally bound to apprehend, or that such other person has committed an offence, or that such other person is a person from whom he has received, or to whom he has given, money or other property by way of gratification for the purpose of inducing him to commit an offence, or of screening him from punishment for an offence already committed, such first-mentioned person is said to 'harbour' such other person. (Exception—This section does not extend to the case in which the harbour is given by the wife or husband of the offender.)

metadata.title_en: Punishments
Construction of References to Transportation
metadata.text_en:
(1) References to 'transportation for life' in any other law for the time being in force, or in any instrument or order made under any such law or in any document, shall be construed as references to 'imprisonment for life'.
        (2) In every case in which a sentence of transportation for a term has been passed before the 1st April, 1957, the offender shall be dealt with in the same manner as if sentenced to rigorous imprisonment for the same term.
        (3) Any reference to 'transportation' in any other law for the time being in force, or in any instrument or order made under any such law or in any document (not being a reference to 'transportation for life') shall, subject to the provisions of sub-section (2), be construed as a reference to 'imprisonment'.

metadata.title_en: Commutation of Sentence of Death
metadata.text_en: In every case in which sentence of death shall have been passed, the Union Government may, without the consent of the offender, commute the punishment for any other punishment provided by this Code.

metadata.title_en: Commutation of Sentence of Imprisonment for Life
metadata.text_en: In every case in which sentence of imprisonment for life shall have been passed, the Union Government may, without the consent of the offender, commute the punishment for imprisonment of either description for a term not exceeding fourteen years.

metadata.title_en: Section 56 is omitted by the Union of Burma (Adaptation of Laws) Order, 1948.
Fractions of Terms of Punishment
metadata.text_en: In calculating fractions of terms of punishment, imprisonment for life shall be reckoned as equivalent to imprisonment for twenty years.

metadata.title_en: Offenders Sentenced to Transportation how Dealt With
metadata.text_en: Section 58 is omitted by the Union of Burma (Adaptation of Laws) Order, 1948.

metadata.title_en: Transportation Instead of Imprisonment
metadata.text_en: Section 59 is omitted by the Union of Burma (Adaptation of Laws) Order, 1948.

metadata.title_en: Sentence of Imprisonment may be (in Certain Cases) Wholly Rigorous or Simple or Partly Rigorous and Partly Simple
metadata.text_en: In every case in which an offender is punishable with imprisonment which may be of either description, it shall be competent to the Court which sentences such offender to direct in the sentence that such imprisonment shall be wholly rigorous, or wholly simple, or that any part of such imprisonment shall be rigorous and the rest simple.

metadata.title_en: Sentence of Forfeiture of Property in Case of Certain Offences
metadata.text_en: Section 61 is omitted by the Union of Burma (Adaptation of Laws) Order, 1948.

metadata.title_en: Forfeiture of Property, in Respect of Offenders Punishable with Death, Transportation or Imprisonment
metadata.text_en: Section 62 is omitted by the Union of Burma (Adaptation of Laws) Order, 1948.

metadata.title_en: Amount of Fine
metadata.text_en: Where no sum is expressed to which a fine may extend, the amount of fine to which the offender is liable is unlimited, but shall not be excessive.

metadata.title_en: Sentence of Imprisonment for Non-Payment of Fine
metadata.text_en: In every case in which an offender is sentenced to a fine, whether with or without imprisonment, and in every case in which an offender is sentenced to imprisonment and also to a fine, in default of payment of the fine, the offender shall be liable to be sentenced by the Court to imprisonment for a certain term, which imprisonment shall be in excess of any other imprisonment to which he may have been sentenced or to which he may be liable under a commutation of a sentence. (The imprisonment which the Court imposes in default of payment of a fine may be of any description to which the offender might have been sentenced for the offence.)

metadata.title_en: Limit of Imprisonment for Non-Payment of Fine, When Imprisonment and Fine Awardable
metadata.text_en: The term for which the Court directs the offender to be imprisoned in default of payment of a fine shall not exceed one-fourth of the maximum term of imprisonment fixed for the offence, if the offence be punishable with imprisonment as well as fine.

metadata.title_en: Description of Imprisonment for Non-Payment of Fine
metadata.text_en: The imprisonment which the Court imposes in default of payment of a fine may be of any description to which the offender might have been sentenced for the offence.

metadata.title_en: Imprisonment for Non-Payment of Fine, When Offence Punishable with Fine Only
metadata.text_en: If the offence be punishable with fine only, the imprisonment which the Court imposes in default of payment of the fine shall be simple, and the term for which the Court directs the offender to be imprisoned, in default of payment of fine, shall not exceed the following scale, that is to say, for any term not exceeding two months, when the amount of the fine shall not exceed fifty kyats; for any term not exceeding four months, when the amount shall not exceed one hundred kyats; and for any term not exceeding six months, in any other case.

metadata.title_en: Imprisonment to Terminate on Payment of Fine
metadata.text_en: The imprisonment which is imposed in default of payment of a fine shall terminate whenever that fine is either paid or levied by process of law.

metadata.title_en: Termination of Imprisonment on Payment of Proportional Part of Fine
metadata.text_en: If, before the expiration of the term of imprisonment fixed in default of payment, such a proportion of the fine be paid or levied that the term of imprisonment suffered in default of payment is not less than proportional to the part of the fine still unpaid, the imprisonment shall terminate.

metadata.title_en: Fine Recoverable Within Six Years, or During Imprisonment - Death of Offender Not to Discharge Property from Liability
metadata.text_en: The fine, or any part thereof which remains unpaid, may be levied at any time within six years after the passing of the sentence, and if the offender be liable to imprisonment for a longer period than six years, then at any time previous to the expiration of that period; and the death of the offender does not discharge from the liability any property which would, after his death, be liable for his debts.

metadata.title_en: Limit of Punishment of Offence Made Up of Several Offences
metadata.text_en: Where anything which is an offence is made up of parts, any of which parts is itself an offence, the offender shall not be punished with the punishment of more than one of such of his offences, unless it be so expressly provided. Where anything is an offence falling within two or more separate definitions of any law in force for the time being, or where several acts, of which one or more than one would by itself or themselves constitute an offence, constitute when combined a different offence, the offender shall not be punished with a more severe punishment than the Court which tries him could award for any one of such offences.

metadata.title_en: Punishment of Persons Guilty of One of Several Offences, the Judgment Stating that it is Doubtful Which
metadata.text_en: In all cases in which judgment is given that a person is guilty of one of several offences specified in the judgment, but that it is doubtful of which of these offences he is guilty, the offender shall be punished for the offence for which the lowest punishment is provided if the same punishment is not provided for all.

metadata.title_en: Solitary Confinement
metadata.text_en:
Whenever any person is convicted of an offence for which under this Code the Court has power to sentence him to rigorous imprisonment, the Court may, by its sentence, order that the offender shall be kept in solitary confinement for any portion or portions of the rigorous imprisonment to which he may be sentenced, not exceeding three months in the whole, according to the following scale, that is to say:
        A time not exceeding one month if the term of imprisonment shall not exceed six months.
        A time not exceeding two months if the term of imprisonment shall exceed six months and shall not exceed one year.
        A time not exceeding three months if the term of imprisonment shall exceed one year.

metadata.title_en: Limit of Solitary Confinement
metadata.text_en: In executing a sentence of solitary confinement, such confinement shall in no case exceed fourteen days at a time, with intervals between the periods of solitary confinement of not less duration than such periods; and when the imprisonment awarded shall exceed three months, the solitary confinement shall not exceed seven days in any one month of the whole imprisonment awarded, with intervals between the periods of solitary confinement of not less duration than such periods.

metadata.title_en: Enhanced Punishment for Certain Offences Under Chapter XII or Chapter XVII After Previous Conviction
metadata.text_en: Whoever, having been convicted of any offence punishable under Chapter XII or Chapter XVII of this Code with imprisonment of either description for a term of three years or upwards, shall commit any offence punishable under either of those Chapters with imprisonment of either description for a term of three years or upwards, shall be liable for every such subsequent offence to imprisonment for life, or to imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years.

metadata.title_en: Act Done by a Person Justified, or by Mistake of Fact Believing Himself Justified, by Law
metadata.text_en: Nothing is an offence which is done by a person who is, or who by reason of a mistake of fact and not by reason of a mistake of law in good faith believes himself to be, bound by law to do it.

metadata.title_en: Act of a Judge When Acting Judicially
metadata.text_en: Nothing is an offence which is done by a Judge when acting judicially in the exercise of any power which is, or which in good faith he believes to be, given to him by law.

metadata.title_en: Act Done Pursuant to the Judgment or Order of a Court of Justice
metadata.text_en: Nothing which is done in pursuance of, or which is warranted by the judgment or order of a Court of Justice, if done whilst such judgment or order remains in force, is an offence, notwithstanding the Court may have had no jurisdiction to pass such judgment or order, provided the person doing the act in good faith believes that the Court had such jurisdiction.

metadata.title_en: Act Done by a Person Justified, or by Mistake of Fact Believing Himself Justified, by Law
metadata.text_en: Nothing is an offence which is done by any person who is justified by law, or who by reason of a mistake of fact and not by reason of a mistake of law in good faith believes himself to be justified by law, in doing it.

metadata.title_en: Accident in Doing a Lawful Act
metadata.text_en: Nothing is an offence which is done by accident or misfortune, and without any criminal intention or knowledge in the doing of a lawful act in a lawful manner by lawful means, and with proper care and caution.

metadata.title_en: Act Likely to Cause Harm, but Done Without Criminal Intent, and to Prevent Other Harm
metadata.text_en: Nothing is an offence merely by reason of its being done with the knowledge that it is likely to cause harm, if it be done without any criminal intention to cause harm, and in good faith for the purpose of preventing or avoiding other harm to person or property. (Illustration—A, the captain of a steam vessel, suddenly and without any fault or negligence on his part, finds himself in such a position that, before he can stop his vessel, he must inevitably run down a boat C, with twenty or thirty passengers on board, unless he changes the course of his vessel; and that, by changing his course, he must inevitably run down a boat D with only two passengers on board. Provided the distress is such as to render it impossible for him to apply to a superior authority, A conscientiously believes that with any other course the death of the passengers on boat C could not be prevented. A changes his course, and intentionally runs down boat D with two passengers on board, giving them the best chance of escape possible in the circumstances. Here, if A was actuated only by the desire of saving the greater number of lives, and not by any malice or mischievous intention towards boat D, his act is not an offence.)

metadata.title_en: Act of a Child Under Seven Years of Age
metadata.text_en: Nothing is an offence which is done by a child under seven years of age.

metadata.title_en: Act of a Child Above Seven and Under Twelve of Immature Understanding
metadata.text_en: Nothing is an offence which is done by a child above seven years of age and under twelve, who has not attained sufficient maturity of understanding to judge of the nature and consequences of his conduct on that occasion.

metadata.title_en: Act of a Person of Unsound Mind
metadata.text_en: Nothing is an offence which is done by a person who at the time of doing it, by reason of unsoundness of mind, is incapable of knowing the nature of the act, or that he is doing what is either wrong or contrary to law.

metadata.title_en: Act of a Person Incapable of Judgment by Reason of Intoxication Caused Against His Will
metadata.text_en: Nothing is an offence which is done by a person who, at the time of doing it, is, by reason of intoxication, incapable of knowing the nature of the act, or that he is doing what is either wrong, or contrary to law: provided that the thing which intoxicated him was administered to him without his knowledge or against his will.

metadata.title_en: Offence Requiring a Particular Intent or Knowledge Committed by One Who is Intoxicated
metadata.text_en: In cases where an act done is not an offence unless done with a particular knowledge or intent, a person who does the act in a state of intoxication shall be liable to be dealt with as if he had the same knowledge as he would have had if he had not been intoxicated, unless the thing which intoxicated him was administered to him without his knowledge or against his will.

metadata.title_en: Act Not Intended to Cause Death or Grievous Hurt, Done by Consent
metadata.text_en: Nothing which is not intended to cause death or grievous hurt, and which is not known by the doer to be likely to cause death or grievous hurt, is an offence by reason of any harm which it may cause, or be intended by the doer to cause, to any person above eighteen years of age, who has given consent, whether express or implied, to suffer that harm; or by reason of any harm which it may be known by the doer to be likely to cause to any such person who has consented to take the risk of that harm.

metadata.title_en: Act Not Intended to Cause Death, Done by Consent in Good Faith for Person's Benefit
metadata.text_en: Nothing which is not intended to cause death, is an offence by reason of any harm which it may cause, or be intended by the doer to cause, or be known by the doer to be likely to cause, to any person for whose benefit it is done in good faith, and who has given a consent, whether express or implied, to suffer that harm, or to take the risk of that harm.

metadata.title_en: Act Done in Good Faith for Benefit of Child or Insane Person, by or by Consent of Guardian
Consent Known to be Given Under Fear or Misconception
metadata.text_en: A consent is not such a consent as is intended by any of the foregoing sections if the consent is given by a person under fear of injury, or under a misconception of fact, and if the person doing the act knows or has reason to believe that the consent was given in consequence of such fear or misconception; or if the consent is given by a person who, from unsoundness of mind or intoxication, is unable to understand the nature and consequence of that to which he gives his consent; or unless the contrary appears from the context, if the consent is given by a child under twelve years of age.

metadata.title_en: Exclusion of Acts Which are Offences Independently of Harm Caused
metadata.text_en: The exceptions in sections 87, 88 and 89 do not extend to acts which are offences independently of any harm which they may cause, or be intended to cause, or be known to be likely to cause, by the person doing them. (Illustration—A, intending to murder Z, administers a poison to Z in consequence of which Z is attacked with a dangerous illness but recovers. These sections do not exempt A from punishment for the attempt to commit murder by reason of the attack of illness, for that is an offence independently of the harm which it intended to cause.)

metadata.title_en: Act Not Intended to Cause Death, Done by Consent in Good Faith for Person's Benefit
Communication Made in Good Faith
metadata.text_en: No communication made in good faith is an offence by reason of any harm to the person to whom it is made, if it is made for the benefit of that person. (Illustration—A, a surgeon, in good faith, communicates to a patient his opinion that he cannot live. The patient dies in consequence of the shock. A has committed no offence, though he knew that the communication was likely to cause the patient's death.)

metadata.title_en: Act to Which a Person is Compelled by Threats
metadata.text_en: Except murder, and offences against the State punishable with death, nothing is an offence which is done by a person who is compelled to do it by threats, which, at the time of doing it, reasonably cause the apprehension that instant death to that person will otherwise be the consequence: Provided that the person doing the act did not of his own accord, or from a reasonable apprehension of harm to himself short of instant death, put himself in the situation where he might be so compelled. (Explanation 1—A person who, of his own accord, or by reason of a threat of being beaten, joins a gang of dacoits, knowing their character, is not entitled to the benefit of this exception, on the ground of his having been compelled by threats to do anything for the gang. Explanation 2—A person seized by a gang of dacoits, and forced by threats, of instant death, to do a thing which is an offence; for example, a smith compelled to take a part in breaking into a house for the purpose of robbery, is entitled to the benefit of this exception.)

metadata.title_en: Act Causing Slight Harm
metadata.text_en: Nothing is an offence by reason that it causes, or that it is intended to cause, or that it is known to be likely to cause, any harm, if that harm is so slight that no person of ordinary sense and temper would complain of such harm. (Illustration—A gives Z a slight push. Z is not hurt, but is offended by the push. A has committed no offence.)

metadata.title_en: Things Done in Private Defence
metadata.text_en: Nothing is an offence which is done in the exercise of the right of private defence.

metadata.section: 97: Right of Private Defence of the Body and of Property
metadata.title_en: Right of Private Defence of the Body and of Property
Right of Private Defence Against the Act of a Person of Unsound Mind, etc.
metadata.text_en: When an act which would otherwise be a certain offence, is not that offence by reason of the youth, the want of maturity of understanding, the unsoundness of mind or the intoxication of the person doing that act, or by reason of any misconception on the part of that person, every person has the same right of private defence against that act which he would have if the act were that offence. (Illustrations—A assaults Z, who is insane. A is not thereby committed an offence, but Z has the same right of private defence which he would have if A were sane. A, in the exercise of his right of private defence, fires at the insane Z. A has committed no offence. A enters by night into Z's house, which he is legally entitled to enter. Z, in good faith, taking A for a dacoit, attacks A. Z has a right of private defence against A, though A commits no offence.)

metadata.title_en: Acts Against Which There is No Right of Private Defence
metadata.text_en: There is no right of private defence against an act which does not reasonably cause the apprehension of death or of grievous hurt, if done, or attempted to be done, by a public servant acting in good faith under colour of his office, though that act may not be strictly justifiable by law. There is no right of private defence against an act which does not reasonably cause the apprehension of death or of grievous hurt, if done, or attempted to be done, by the direction of a public servant acting in good faith under colour of his office, though that direction may not be strictly justifiable by law. There is no right of private defence in cases in which there is time to have recourse to the protection of the public authorities. The right of private defence in no case extends to the inflicting of more harm than it is necessary to inflict for the purpose of defence. (Explanation 1—A person is not deprived of the right of private defence against an act done by a public servant, unless he knows, or has reason to believe, that the person doing the act is such public servant. Explanation 2—A person is not deprived of the right of private defence against an act done by the direction of a public servant, unless he knows, or has reason to believe, that the person doing the act acts by such direction, or unless he knows, or has reason to believe, that the person doing the act is such public servant.)

metadata.title_en: When the Right of Private Defence of the Body Extends to Causing Death
When Such Right Does Not Extend to Causing Death
metadata.text_en: If the offence be not of any of the descriptions enumerated in the last preceding section, the right of private defence of the body does not extend to the voluntary causing of death to the assailant, but does extend, under the restrictions mentioned in section 99, to the voluntary causing to the assailant of any harm other than death.

metadata.title_en: Commencement and Continuance of the Right of Private Defence of the Body
metadata.text_en: The right of private defence of the body commences as soon as a reasonable apprehension of danger to the body arises from an attempt or threat to commit the offence, though the offence may not have been committed; and it continues as long as such apprehension of danger to the body continues.

metadata.title_en: When the Right of Private Defence of Property Extends to Causing Death
When Such Right Does Not Extend to Causing Death
metadata.text_en: If the offence, the committing of which, or the attempting to commit which, occasions the exercise of the right of private defence, be theft, mischief or criminal trespass, not of any of the descriptions enumerated in the last preceding section, that right does not extend to the voluntary causing of death, but does extend, subject to the restrictions mentioned in section 99, to the voluntary causing to the wrongdoer of any harm other than death.

metadata.title_en: Commencement and Continuance of the Right of Private Defence of Property
metadata.text_en: The right of private defence of property commences when a reasonable apprehension of danger to the property commences. The right of private defence of property against theft continues till the offender has effected his retreat with the property, or till the assistance of the public authorities has been obtained, or till the property has been recovered. The right of private defence of property against robbery continues as long as the offender causes or attempts to cause to any person death or hurt or wrongful restraint, or as long as the fear of instant death or of instant hurt or of instant wrongful restraint continues. The right of private defence of property against criminal trespass or mischief continues as long as the criminal trespass or mischief continues. The right of private defence of property against house-breaking by night continues as long as the house-trespass which has been committed in order to commit house-breaking by night continues.

metadata.title_en: Right of Private Defence Against Deadly Assault When There is Risk of Harm to Innocent Person
metadata.text_en: If in the exercise of the right of private defence against an assault which reasonably causes the apprehension of death, the defender be so situated that he cannot effectually exercise that right without risk of harm to an innocent person, his right of private defence extends to the running of that risk. (Illustration—A is attacked by a mob who attempt to murder him. He cannot effectually use his right of private defence without firing on the mob, and he cannot fire without risk of hurting young children who are mingled with the mob. A commits no offence if he fires on the mob.)

metadata.title_en: Abetment of a Thing
metadata.text_en:
A person abets the doing of a thing, who—
        First—Instigates any person to do that thing; or
        Secondly—Engages with one or more other person or persons in any conspiracy for the doing of that thing, if an act or illegal omission takes place in pursuance of that conspiracy, and in order to the doing of that thing; or
        Thirdly—Intentionally aids, by any act or illegal omission, the doing of that thing. (Explanation 1—A person who, by willful misrepresentation, or by willful concealment of a material fact which he is bound to disclose, voluntarily causes or procures, or attempts to cause or procure, a thing to be done, is said to instigate the doing of that thing. Illustration—A, a public officer, is authorized by a warrant from a Court of Justice to apprehend Z. B, knowing that fact and also that C is not Z, wilfully represents to A that C is Z, and thereby intentionally causes A to apprehend C. Here B abets by instigation the apprehension of C by A. Explanation 2—Whoever, either prior to or at the time of the commission of an act, does anything in order to facilitate the commission of that act, and thereby facilitates the commission thereof, is said to aid the doing of that act.)

metadata.title_en: Abettor
metadata.text_en: A person abets an offence, who abets either the commission of an offence, or the commission of an act which would be an offence, if committed by a person capable by law of committing an offence with the same intention or knowledge as that of the abettor. (Explanation 1—A person who instigates another to do a thing, and consequently the thing is done by the person instigated, is said to abet the thing's being done by the other person, and not to abet the other person in doing the thing. Illustration—A instigates B to murder C. B murders C in consequence of the instigation. A is an abettor of the murder of C. Explanation 2—To constitute the offence of abetment, it is not necessary that the act abetted should be committed, or that the effect requisite to constitute the offence should be caused. Illustration—A instigates B to murder D. B refuses to do so. A is nevertheless guilty of abetting B to murder D. Explanation 3—It is not necessary that the person abetted should be capable by law of committing an offence, or that he should have the same guilty intention or knowledge as that of the abettor, or any guilty intention or knowledge. Illustration—A, with a guilty intention, abets a child, or a lunatic, to commit an act which would be an offence if committed by a person of sound mind who is of full age. The child or lunatic commits the act instigated by A. Here A is guilty of abetting an offence, notwithstanding that the child or lunatic is incapable by law of committing an offence. Explanation 4—The abetment of an offence being an offence, the abetment of such an abetment is also an offence. Illustration—A instigates B to instigate C to murder D. B accordingly instigates C to murder D, and C murders D. B is guilty of abetting murder, and A is guilty of abetting B to abet murder. Explanation 5—It is not necessary to the commission of the offence of abetment that the person abetted should do the act with a guilty knowledge or intention corresponding to that of the abettor. Illustration—A instigates B to set fire to a dwelling-house. B, in consequence of A's instigation, sets fire to the house and thereby commits mischief. B does not know that it is a dwelling-house. A is guilty of abetting an offence, and B is guilty of committing mischief.)

metadata.title_en: Punishment of Abetment if the Act Abetted is Committed in Consequence and Where No Express Provision is Made for its Punishment
metadata.text_en: Whoever abets any offence shall, if the act abetted is committed in consequence of the abetment, and no express provision is made by this Code for the punishment of such abetment, be punished with the punishment provided for the offence. (Explanation—An act or offence is said to be committed in consequence of abetment, when it is committed through the instigation, or with the aid, or in pursuance of the conspiracy, which constitutes the abetment. Illustrations—A instigates B to give false evidence. B, in consequence of that instigation, commits that offence. A is guilty of abetting that offence, and is liable to the same punishment as B. A instigates B to murder C. B refuses to do so. A is nevertheless liable to punishment. A instigates B to strike C. B strikes C. A is liable to punishment accordingly. A instigates B to strike C. C is not present when the instigation takes place. B goes and strikes C. Here B has committed the offence of voluntarily causing hurt. A is liable to the same punishment for abetment as B is for causing hurt. )

metadata.title_en: Punishment of Abetment if Person Abetted Does Act with Different Intention from that of Abettor
metadata.text_en: Whoever abets the commission of an offence shall, if the person abetted does the act with a different intention or knowledge from that of the abettor, be punished with the punishment provided for the offence which would have been committed if the act had been done by the abettor with his own intention and knowledge and not with the intention or knowledge of the person abetted. (Illustration—A instigates B to burn Z's house. B sets fire to the house intending to commit mischief, but not knowing that the house is Z's house. B has committed mischief, and is punishable under section 435. A is guilty of abetting arson, and is punishable under section 436.)

metadata.title_en: Liability of Abettor When One Act Abetted and Different Act Done
metadata.text_en: When an act is abetted and a different act is done, the abettor is liable for the act done, in the same manner and to the same extent as if he had directly abetted it: Provided the act done was a probable consequence of the abetment, and was committed under the influence of the instigation, or with the aid or in pursuance of the conspiracy which constituted the abetment. (Illustrations—A instigates B to injure Z grievously. B, in consequence of the instigation, causes grievous hurt to Z. A is liable to punishment. A instigates B to rob C. B, in consequence of the instigation, robs C, and while doing so voluntarily causes grievous hurt to C. Here, if A knew that B was likely voluntarily to cause grievous hurt in robbing C, A is liable to punishment as for abetting voluntarily causing grievous hurt. If A did not know that B was likely voluntarily to cause grievous hurt, A is liable only to punishment for abetting robbery. )

metadata.title_en: Liability of Abettor for Act Done in Consequence of Abetment and for Act Aided and Abetted
metadata.text_en: If the act for which the abettor is liable under the last preceding section is committed in addition to the act which was abetted, and constitutes a distinct offence, the abettor is liable to punishment for each of the offences.

metadata.title_en: Liability of Abettor for an Effect Caused by the Act Abetted Different from that Intended by Abettor
metadata.text_en: When an act is abetted with the intention on the part of the abettor of causing a particular effect, and an act for which the abettor is liable in consequence of the abetment causes a different effect, the abettor is liable for the effect caused, provided he knew that the act abetted was likely to cause that different effect. (Illustration—A instigates B to cause grievous hurt to Z. B, in consequence of the instigation, causes grievous hurt to Z. In consequence of the grievous hurt, Z dies. Here if A knew that the grievous hurt was likely to cause death, A is liable to punishment for murder. )

metadata.title_en: Abettor Present When Offence is Committed
metadata.text_en: Whenever any person, who is abetting the commission of an offence, is present at the time when the offence is committed, he shall be deemed to have committed such offence.

metadata.title_en: Abetment of Offence Punishable with Death or Imprisonment for Life—if Offence Not Committed—if Act Causing Harm Done in Consequence
metadata.text_en: Whoever abets the commission of an offence punishable with death or imprisonment for life, shall, if that offence be not committed in consequence of the abetment, and no express provision is made by this Code for the punishment of such abetment, be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine; and if any act for which the abettor is liable in consequence of the abetment, and which causes hurt to any person, is done, the abettor shall be liable to imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to fourteen years, and shall also be liable to fine. (Illustration—A instigates B to murder Z. The offence of murder is not committed. If A is not punishable under section 118, he shall be punished with imprisonment for a term which may extend to seven years, and also be liable to fine. )

metadata.title_en: Abetment of Offence Punishable with Imprisonment—if Offence Not Committed
metadata.text_en: Whoever abets an offence punishable with imprisonment of any description for a term, or with fine, or with both, shall, if that offence be not committed in consequence of the abetment, and no express provision is made by this Code for the punishment of such abetment, be punished with imprisonment of any description provided for that offence for a term which may extend to one-fourth part of the longest term provided for that offence, or with such fine as is provided for the offence, or with both; and if the abettor or the person abetted is a public servant, whose duty it is to prevent the offence, the abettor shall be punished with imprisonment of any description provided for that offence for a term which may extend to one-half of the longest term provided for that offence, or with such fine as is provided for the offence, or with both. (Illustration—A abets by instigation an insurrection against the Government of the Union of Burma. The insurrection does not take place. A is punishable by section 116. )

metadata.title_en: Abetting Commission of Offence by the Public, or by More Than Ten Persons
metadata.text_en: Whoever abets the commission of an offence by the public generally, or by any number or class of persons exceeding ten, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both. (Illustration—A affixes in a public place a placard instigating a sect, as such, to commit violence against any other sect. A is punishable under this section.)

metadata.title_en: Concealing Design to Commit Offence Punishable with Death or Imprisonment for Life
metadata.text_en: Whoever intending to facilitate or knowing it to be likely that he will thereby facilitate the commission of an offence punishable with death or imprisonment for life, voluntarily conceals by any act or illegal omission, the existence of a design to commit such offence, or makes any representation which he knows to be false respecting such design, shall, if that offence be committed, be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, or, if the offence be not committed, with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years; and in either case shall also be liable to fine. (Illustration—A knowing that B is about to commit a dacoity, conceals the fact that an armed force has been sent into the neighbourhood to apprehend the dacoits. This is punishable under this section.)

metadata.title_en: Public servant concealing design to commit offence which it is his duty to prevent
metadata.text_en: Whoever, being a public servant, intending to facilitate or knowing it to be likely that he will thereby facilitate the commission of an offence the commission of which it is his duty as such public servant to prevent, voluntarily conceals by any act or illegal omission, or by the concealment of any design to commit that offence, or makes any representation which he knows to be false, or does any other thing which he knows to be likely to prevent the prevention of that offence, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both; if the offence is punishable with death, etc.

metadata.title_en: Concealing design to commit offence punishable with imprisonment
metadata.text_en: Whoever, intending to facilitate or knowing it to be likely that he will thereby facilitate the commission of an offence punishable with imprisonment, voluntarily conceals by any act or illegal omission, or by the concealment of any design to commit that offence, or makes any representation which he knows to be false, or does any other thing which he knows to be likely to prevent the prevention of that offence, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one-fourth part of the longest term of imprisonment provided for the offence, or with fine, or with both.

metadata.title_en: Definition of criminal conspiracy
metadata.text_en:
When two or more persons agree to do, or cause to be done—
        (1) an illegal act, or
        (2) an act which is not illegal by illegal means, such an agreement is designated a criminal conspiracy: Provided that no agreement except an agreement to commit an offence shall amount to a criminal conspiracy unless some act besides the agreement is done by one or more parties to such agreement in pursuance of the agreement. It is immaterial whether the illegal act is the ultimate object of such agreement, or is merely incidental to that object.

metadata.title_en: Punishment of criminal conspiracy
metadata.text_en:
(1) Whoever is a party to a criminal conspiracy to commit an offence punishable with death, imprisonment for life or rigorous imprisonment for a term of two years or upwards, shall, where no express provision is made in this Code for the punishment of such a conspiracy, be punished in the same manner as if he had abetted such offence.
        (2) Whoever is a party to a criminal conspiracy other than a criminal conspiracy to commit an offence punishable as aforesaid shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term not exceeding six months, or with fine, or with both.

metadata.title_en: Waging, or attempting to wage war, or abetting waging of war, against the Union
metadata.text_en: Whoever wages war against the Union, or attempts to wage such war, or abets the waging of such war, shall be punished with death, or imprisonment for life, and shall also be liable to fine.

metadata.title_en: Conspiracy to commit offences punishable by section 121
metadata.text_en: Whoever within or without Myanmar conspires to commit any of the offences punishable by section 121, or to deprive the Union of the sovereignty of Myanmar or of any part thereof, or of any of its Union territories, or of any of its dependencies, or of any of its possessions, or of any part of such sovereignty, or of any such territory or dependency or possession, or to overthrow by criminal force or show of criminal force the Union Government, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

metadata.title_en: Collecting arms, etc., with intention of waging war against the Union
metadata.text_en: Whoever collects men, arms or ammunition or otherwise prepares to wage war with the intention of either waging or being prepared to wage war against the Union, shall be punished with imprisonment for life or rigorous imprisonment for a term not exceeding ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

metadata.title_en: Concealing design to wage war
metadata.text_en: Whoever, by any act or illegal omission, conceals the existence of a design to wage war against the Union, intending by such concealment to facilitate, or knowing it to be likely that such concealment will facilitate, the waging of such war, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, or with fine, or with both.

metadata.title_en: Assaulting President, etc., with intention to compel or restrain the exercise of any lawful power
metadata.text_en: Whoever, with the intention of inducing or compelling the President of the Union, or the Union Government, or any State or Region Government, or any public servant, to exercise or refrain from exercising in any manner any of the lawful powers of the President of the Union, or of the Union Government, or of any State or Region Government, or of any public servant, assaults or wrongfully restrains or attempts wrongfully to restrain, or overawes by means of criminal force or the show of criminal force, or attempts so to overawe, the President of the Union, or the Union Government, or any State or Region Government, or any public servant, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.

metadata.title_en: Sedition
metadata.text_en: Whoever, by words, either spoken or written, or by signs, or by visible representation, or otherwise, brings or attempts to bring into hatred or contempt, or excites or attempts to excite disaffection towards, the Union Government or any State or Region Government constituted by law in Myanmar, or the Tatmadaw or the Union or a State or Region or other public service, or the administration of justice in Myanmar, shall be punished with imprisonment for life or with imprisonment which may extend to seven years, or with fine, or with both. Explanation 1.—The expression "disaffection" includes disloyalty and all feelings of enmity. Explanation 2.—Comments expressing disapprobation of the measures of the Union Government or any State or Region Government, or the Tatmadaw or the Union or a State or Region or other public service, or the administration of justice in Myanmar, without exciting or attempting to excite hatred, contempt or disaffection, do not constitute an offence under this section. Explanation 3.—Comments expressing disapprobation of the administrative or other action of the Union Government or any State or Region Government, or the Tatmadaw or the Union or a State or Region or other public service, or the administration of justice in Myanmar, without exciting or attempting to excite hatred, contempt or disaffection, do not constitute an offence under this section.

metadata.title_en: Waging war against any Asiatic power in alliance with the Union Government
metadata.text_en: Whoever wages war against any Asiatic power in alliance or at peace with the Union Government, or attempts to wage such war, or abets the waging of such war, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, to which fine may be added, or with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, to which fine may be added, or with fine.

metadata.title_en: Committing depredation on territories of Power at peace with the Union Government
metadata.text_en: Whoever commits depredation, or makes preparations to commit depredation, on the territories of any Power in alliance or at peace with the Union Government, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine, and to forfeiture of any property acquired by such depredation.

metadata.title_en: Receiving property taken by war or depredation mentioned in sections 125 and 126
metadata.text_en: Whoever receives any property knowing the same to have been taken in the commission of any of the offences mentioned in sections 125 and 126 shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine, and to forfeiture of the property so received.

metadata.title_en: Public servant voluntarily allowing escape of prisoner of State or war
metadata.text_en: Whoever, being a public servant and having the custody of any State prisoner or prisoner of war, voluntarily allows such prisoner to escape from any place in which such prisoner is confined, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

metadata.title_en: Public servant negligently suffering escape of such prisoner
metadata.text_en: Whoever, being a public servant and having the custody of any State prisoner or prisoner of war, negligently suffers such prisoner to escape from any place of confinement, shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to three years, and shall also be liable to fine.

metadata.title_en: Aiding escape of, rescuing or harbouring such prisoner
metadata.text_en: Whoever knowingly aids or assists any State prisoner or prisoner of war in escaping from lawful custody, or rescues or attempts to rescue any such prisoner, or harbours or conceals any such prisoner, knowing him to be such prisoner, and intending to prevent his being recaptured, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine. Exception.—This provision does not extend to the case in which the harbour or concealment is by the wife or husband of the offender.

metadata.title_en: Abetting mutiny, or attempting to seduce a soldier, sailor or airman from his duty
metadata.text_en: Whoever abets the committing of mutiny by an officer, soldier, sailor or airman in the Army, Navy or Air Force of the Union Government, or attempts to seduce any such officer, soldier, sailor or airman from his allegiance to the Union Government or his duty as such officer, soldier, sailor or airman, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

metadata.title_en: Abetment of mutiny, if mutiny committed in consequence thereof
metadata.text_en: Whoever abets the committing of mutiny by an officer, soldier, sailor or airman in the Army, Navy or Air Force of the Union Government, if mutiny be committed in consequence of that abetment, shall be punished with death or with imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

metadata.title_en: Abetment of assault by soldier, sailor or airman on his superior officer, when in execution of his office
metadata.text_en: Whoever abets an assault by an officer, soldier, sailor or airman in the Army, Navy or Air Force of the Union Government, on his superior officer being in the execution of his office, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.

metadata.title_en: Abetment of such assault if the assault is committed
metadata.text_en: Whoever abets an assault by an officer, soldier, sailor or airman in the Army, Navy or Air Force of the Union Government, on his superior officer, if such assault be committed in consequence of that abetment, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, or with fine, or with both.

metadata.title_en: Abetment of desertion of soldier, sailor or airman
metadata.text_en: Whoever abets the desertion of any officer, soldier, sailor or airman in the Army, Navy or Air Force of the Union Government, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

metadata.title_en: Harbouring deserter
metadata.text_en: Whoever, except in the case of a wife or husband, harbours or conceals any deserter, knowing or having reason to believe him to be such, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

metadata.title_en: Deserter concealed on board merchant vessel through negligence of master
metadata.text_en: If any person being a master of a merchant vessel, which is in any harbour, port or river subject to the laws of Myanmar, knowingly receives or retains on board such vessel, or aids in concealing in such vessel, any deserter from the Army, Navy or Air Force of the Union Government, or refuses to give up on demand any such deserter whom he may have concealed, or on board whose vessel such deserter may be concealed, the master or person in charge of the vessel shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

metadata.title_en: Abetment of act of insubordination by soldier, sailor or airman
metadata.text_en: Whoever abets any act of insubordination by an officer, soldier, sailor or airman in the Army, Navy or Air Force of the Union Government, to such an extent as to cause mutiny, if such act of insubordination be committed in consequence of that abetment, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine, or with both.

metadata.title_en: Persons subject to certain Acts
metadata.text_en: No person subject to the Army Act, Navy Act or Air Force Act of the Union Government is subject to punishment under this Code for any of the offences defined in this Chapter.

metadata.title_en: Wearing garb or carrying token used by soldier, sailor or airman
metadata.text_en: Whoever, not being a soldier, sailor or airman in the Army, Navy or Air Force of the Union Government, wears any garb or carries any token resembling any garb or token used by a soldier, sailor or airman in the Army, Navy or Air Force of the Union Government, with the intention that it may be believed that he is such a soldier, sailor or airman, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three months, or with fine which may extend to five hundred kyats, or with both.

metadata.title_en: Unlawful Assembly
metadata.text_en: An assembly of five or more persons is designated an 'unlawful assembly' if the common object of the persons composing that assembly is to commit any offence.

metadata.title_en: Being Member of Unlawful Assembly
metadata.text_en: Whoever, being aware of facts which render any assembly an unlawful assembly, intentionally joins that assembly, or continues in it, is said to be a member of an unlawful assembly.

metadata.title_en: Punishment for Unlawful Assembly
metadata.text_en: Whoever is a member of an unlawful assembly shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine, or with both.

metadata.title_en: Joining Unlawful Assembly Armed with Deadly Weapon
metadata.text_en: Whoever, being armed with any deadly weapon, or with anything which, used as a weapon of offence, is likely to cause death, is a member of an unlawful assembly, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

metadata.title_en: Joining or Continuing in Unlawful Assembly, Knowing It Has Been Commanded to Disperse
metadata.text_en: Whoever joins or continues in an unlawful assembly, knowing that such unlawful assembly has been commanded in the manner prescribed by law to disperse, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

metadata.title_en: Rioting
metadata.text_en: Whenever force or violence is used by an unlawful assembly, or by any member thereof, in prosecution of the common object of such assembly, every member of such assembly is guilty of the offence of rioting.

metadata.title_en: Punishment for Rioting
metadata.text_en: Whoever is guilty of rioting shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

metadata.title_en: Rioting, Armed with Deadly Weapon
metadata.text_en: Whoever is guilty of rioting, being armed with any deadly weapon or with anything which, used as a weapon of offence, is likely to cause death, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.

metadata.title_en: Every Member of Unlawful Assembly Guilty of Offence Committed in Prosecution of Common Object
metadata.text_en: If an offence is committed by any member of an unlawful assembly in prosecution of the common object of that assembly, or such as the members of that assembly knew to be likely to be committed in prosecution of that object, every person who at the time of the committing of that offence is a member of the same assembly, is guilty of that offence.

metadata.title_en: Hiring, or Inducing to Hire, Persons to Join Unlawful Assembly or Rioting
metadata.text_en: Whoever hires or engages or employs or for any purpose instigates, or knowingly, or having reason to believe that such persons are about to be hired, engaged, or employed, or are likely to be instigated to join or become members of any unlawful assembly or to take part in any riot, or to abet the same, and by any such hiring, engagement, or employment or instigation, actually causes any persons to join or become members of any unlawful assembly, or to take part in any riot, or to abet the same, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to five years, or with fine, or with both.

metadata.title_en: Knowingly Joining or Continuing in Assembly of Five or More Persons After It Has Been Commanded to Disperse
metadata.text_en: Whoever knowingly joins or continues in any assembly of five or more persons likely to cause a disturbance of the public peace, after such assembly has been commanded to disperse, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine, or with both.

metadata.title_en: Assaulting or Obstructing Public Servant When Suppressing Riot, etc.
metadata.text_en: Whoever assaults or obstructs any public servant in the discharge of his duty as such public servant in endeavouring to disperse an unlawful assembly or to suppress a riot or affray, or uses or attempts to use criminal force or show of criminal force to such public servant, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.

metadata.title_en: Wantonly Giving Provocation with Intent to Cause Riot
metadata.text_en: Whoever malignantly or wantonly by doing anything which is illegal, or by means which are illegal, gives provocation to any person intending or knowing it to be likely that such provocation will cause the offence of rioting to be committed, shall, if the offence of rioting be committed in consequence of such provocation, be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both; and if the offence of rioting be not committed, with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine, or with both.

metadata.title_en: Promoting Enmity Between Classes
metadata.text_en: Whoever by words, either spoken or written, or by signs, or by visible representations, or otherwise, promotes or attempts to promote feelings of enmity or hatred between different classes of the citizens of Myanmar, shall be punished with imprisonment for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

metadata.title_en: Owner or Occupier of Land on Which Unlawful Assembly Is Held
metadata.text_en: Whenever any unlawful assembly or riot takes place, the owner or occupier of the land on which such unlawful assembly is held, or such riot is committed, and any person having or claiming an interest in such land, shall be punishable with fine not exceeding one thousand kyats, if he or his agent or manager, knowing that such offence is being or has been committed, or having reason to believe that it is likely to be committed, does not give the earliest notice thereof to the nearest police-station or to the nearest public servant.

metadata.title_en: Liability of Person for Whose Benefit Riot Is Committed
metadata.text_en: Whenever a riot is committed for the benefit or on behalf of any person, such person shall be punishable with fine, if he or his agent or manager, having reason to believe that such riot was likely to be committed, or that persons in his employ or under his control were likely to commit such riot, does not give the earliest notice thereof to the nearest police-station or to the nearest public servant.

metadata.title_en: Liability of Agent or Manager for Whose Benefit Riot Is Committed
metadata.text_en: Whenever a riot is committed for the benefit or on behalf of any person, the agent or manager of such person shall be punishable with fine, if he, having reason to believe that such riot was likely to be committed, or that persons in his employ or under his control were likely to commit such riot, does not give the earliest notice thereof to the nearest police-station or to the nearest public servant.

metadata.title_en: Harbouring Persons Hired for an Unlawful Assembly or Riot
metadata.text_en: Whoever harbours, receives, or assembles in any house or premises in his occupation or charge, or under his control, any persons knowing that such persons have been hired, engaged, or employed, or are about to be hired, engaged, or employed, to join or become members of an unlawful assembly, or to take part in a riot, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

metadata.title_en: Being Hired to Take Part in an Unlawful Assembly or Riot
metadata.text_en: Whoever is engaged, or acts, or is hired to act, as a member of any unlawful assembly, or to take part in a riot, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine, or with both.

metadata.title_en: Affray
metadata.text_en: When two or more persons by fighting in a public place disturb the public peace, they are said to commit an 'affray'.

metadata.title_en: Punishment for Committing Affray
metadata.text_en: Whoever commits an affray shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one month, or with fine which may extend to one hundred kyats, or with both.

metadata.title_en: Public servant taking gratification in respect of an official act
metadata.text_en: Whoever, being or expecting to be a public servant, accepts or obtains, or agrees to accept or attempts to obtain, from any person, for himself or for any other person, any gratification whatever, other than legal remuneration, as a motive or reward for doing or forbearing to do any official act, or for showing or forbearing to show, in the exercise of his official functions, favour or disfavour to any person, or for rendering or attempting to render any service or disservice to any person, with the Union Government or Parliament or the Government of any State or the Legislature of any State, or with any public servant as such, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.

metadata.title_en: Taking gratification, in order to influence public servant, by corrupt or illegal means
metadata.text_en: Whoever accepts or obtains, or agrees to accept or attempts to obtain, from any person, for himself or for any other person, any gratification whatever as a motive or reward for inducing, by corrupt or illegal means, any public servant to do or to forbear to do any official act, or in the exercise of the official functions of such public servant to show favour or disfavour to any person, or to render or attempt to render any service or disservice to any person, with the Union Government or Parliament or the Government of any State or the Legislature of any State, or with any public servant as such, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.

metadata.title_en: Taking gratification for exercise of personal influence with public servant
metadata.text_en: Whoever accepts or obtains, or agrees to accept or attempts to obtain, from any person, for himself or for any other person, any gratification whatever, as a motive or reward for inducing any public servant, by the exercise of personal influence, to do or to forbear to do any official act, or in the exercise of the official functions of such public servant to show favour or disfavour to any person, or to render or attempt to render any service or disservice to any person, with the Union Government or Parliament or the Government of any State or the Legislature of any State, or with any public servant as such, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.

metadata.title_en: Punishment for abetment by public servant of offences defined in section 162 or 163
metadata.text_en: Whoever, being a public servant, abets any offence punishable under section 162 or 163, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.

metadata.title_en: Public servant obtaining valuable thing, without consideration, from person concerned in any proceeding or business transacted by such public servant
metadata.text_en: Whoever, being a public servant, accepts or obtains, or agrees to accept or attempts to obtain, for himself or for any other person, any valuable thing without consideration, or for a consideration which he knows to be inadequate, from any person whom he knows to have been, or to be, or to be likely to be, concerned in any proceeding or business transacted or about to be transacted by such public servant, or having any connection with the official functions of such public servant, or with whom such public servant has had, or is likely to have, any dealings, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

metadata.title_en: Public servant disobeying law, with intent to cause injury to any person
metadata.text_en: Whoever, being a public servant, knowingly disobeys any direction of the law as to the way in which he is to conduct himself as such public servant, intending to cause, or knowing it to be likely that he will thereby cause, injury to any person, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both.

metadata.title_en: Public servant framing an incorrect document with intent to cause injury
metadata.text_en: Whoever, being a public servant, and being charged with the preparation or translation of any document, frames or translates that document in a manner which he knows or believes to be incorrect, intending thereby to cause injury to any person, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.

metadata.title_en: Public servant unlawfully engaging in trade or unlawfully buying or bidding for property
metadata.text_en: Whoever, being a public servant, and being legally bound not to engage in trade, or not to buy or bid for any property, yet engages in trade, or buys or bids for property, either in his own name or in the name of another, or jointly with others, or in shares, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both; and if he buys, the property shall be confiscated.

metadata.title_en: Public servant unlawfully buying or bidding for property
metadata.text_en: Whoever, being a public servant, and being legally bound not to buy or bid for certain property, yet buys or bids for that property, either in his own name or in the name of another, or jointly with others, or in shares, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both; and if he buys, the property shall be confiscated.

metadata.title_en: Personating a public servant
metadata.text_en: Whoever pretends to hold any particular office as a public servant, knowing that he does not hold such office, and in such assumed character does or attempts to do any act under colour of such office, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

metadata.title_en: Wearing garb or carrying token used by public servant with fraudulent intent
